Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Biological Materials and Processes (BioMaP)

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This renewal of a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at Iowa State University entitled, Biological Materials and Processes (BioMaP), will create novel research experiences for a talented and diverse group of undergraduate students from traditionally underrepresented populations, with limited access to STEM research opportunities. The cross-disciplinary nature of BioMaP enables students to discover the exciting biology/interface and will focus on two research themes. (1) Biological Materials - The interface between biology and materials can be exploited to design robust materials with unique properties. In this context, biological materials are synthetic materials that interact with biological molecules/systems in specific ways to promote biological function. The students will work on projects that include working with new techniques for using bacteriophages as sensors, new thermochemical processing methods for biomass in fluidized bed reactors, and new biosensors for use in pancreatic cancer diagnostics. (2) Biological Processes - A fundamental knowledge of biological processes will be critical in the future chemical industry. Students will be exposed to this area through projects on protein recovery from transgenic plants, molecular modeling of peptide mimics, and metabolic engineering of alkaloids. Students will be exposed to exciting research experiences of working in a global environment where their research will evolve from dependent to independent status and they will attain life-long learning skills that will impact their contributions to engineering, science and society.

Over a three year period, this REU Site program will engage undergraduate students in a 10-week intensive, summer research experience focused on the two research themes of Biological Materials and Biological Processes. The students will be active members of inter-disciplinary groups and will interact with a faculty team that is diverse, has broad research interests and an outstanding record of mentoring undergraduate students. The REU students will participate in cohort experiences such as short courses, joint seminars/meetings, workshops, tours of research facilities, and field trips. Formalized written reports and poster presentations will be used to develop communication skills and significant follow-up will insure that the participants are given the greatest opportunity to pursue careers in Chemical and Biological Engineering. At the end of the summer program, the students will participate in a joint poster symposium together with students from other ISU undergraduate research programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The BioMaP REU Program was offered in the summers of 2016-18. A comprehensive and content-rich website (http://www.cbe.iastate.edu/research/undergraduate-research/) was maintained that described the application process, research projects, contact information for faculty and staff, and other programmatic details. A flyer was prepared that described the program and sent via electronic mail to chairs of more than 100 chemical engineering and about 60 biomedical engineering programs nationwide. The application form was made available online on the BioMaP website. Arrangements were also made to house the students in Frederiksen Court on the Iowa State University (ISU) campus.

Typically, the students were required to submit their application by February 15. Over three years, the program averaged 151 applicants/year. The co-PIs and a subcommittee of faculty mentors evaluated the applications and reached consensus to make offers. This NSF grant provided funding for 30 students over three years.  The co-PIs leveraged matching funds from ISU, and partnerships with other externally funded programs on campus, such as the Iowa EPSCoR and LSAMP-IINSPIRE were used to fund 4 additional students, bringing the total number of students funded by the program in three years to 34. Of these students, 50% were female and 23% were underrepresented minorities. In most cases, students received their first or second choices (as indicated in their application) for research project, and as soon as the students accepted, the faculty mentors sent them information about the project and the research group to enable the students to start familiarizing themselves with the project.

The BioMaP REU students participated in the writing of refereed journal publications and presented their work regional and national conferences, like the American Institute of Chemical Engineers (AIChE) Annual Meeting. The complete list is shown below. More publications are anticipated to be submitted in 2019.

Four of the REU students won awards for research performed as part of the BioMaP REU. Mr. Logan Morton (third place) and Ms. Merjem Mededovic (second place) won awards in their respective divisions at the Undergraduate Poster Competition at the 2017 Annual AIChE Meeting. Two students, Mr. Matthew Amrofell and Mr. Adam Carr, won third place in their respective divisions at the Undergraduate Poster Competition at the 2016 Annual AIChE Meeting.

The research performed by the students in the area of biological materials and processes has led to new techniques for using bacteriophages as sensors, new thermochemical processing methods for biomass in fluidized bed reactors, an improved computational model for flow in photobioreactors, new strategies for deriving coarse-grained molecular models of nucleic acids, and new extracellular matrix environments for use in studying breast cancer.

Program evaluation: The Research Institute for Studies in Education (RISE) conducted annual program evaluations in 2017 and 2018. Overall, students expressed great satisfaction with the academic and social components of the program. Students appreciated the efforts to emphasize activities that included research projects, small group discussions and social events. Students were pleased with the interactions they had with faculty mentors and graduate students and with the opportunities for networking with other REU students. The evaluation was carried out using participant surveys and mentor (faculty and graduate student) surveys. Students responded to a variety of questions on graduate school plans, suggestions for improvements to the program, and overall satisfaction with the program. Aspects of the program that were deemed significant by students included an opportunity to be first author on a journal article, learning more about the research process, influence on their thinking about graduate school, and interacting with students from different geographical and cultural backgrounds. Overall students indicated that the REU experience had confirmed their career goals and helped them learn more about graduate school. Students also indicated that they would strongly recommend this REU program to other undergraduates.

The BioMaP REU Program was highly successful, based on the comments and feedback received from the students and the faculty. We have already seen several of the REU students from our program being accepted into Ph.D. programs and several more are in the process of evaluating offers from graduate programs. This was a very satisfactory experience for the co-PIs and their colleagues (including the support staff and the graduate student mentors) and we look forward to doing this again in 2019 and beyond.
